title: Earl Shilton Building Society charges £10 fees on Faster Payment withdrawals
text:
A saver with Earl Shilton has complained about the building society charging £10 to withdraw cash from its easy access savings account.

Leicestershire-based Earl Shilton Building Society, which celebrated its 160th anniversary in 2017 and has 'over 10,000 members', does not allow users to transfer money out of its savings accounts online.

Instead, savers must either write in by post to make an electronic transfer request, or go into its Earl Shilton and Barwell branches - two villages around 12 miles outside of the city of Leicester.

But unless you want cash over the counter or a cheque sent out, the building society charges £10 for withdrawals made by the Faster Payments system, which can arrive immediately or within a day, or £30 for cash via CHAPS payments.

Earl Shilton Building Society has two branches in Leicestershire, and around 10,000 members

The saver, who asked not to be named, said: 'I am not sure Joe Public would even think to apply the concept of withdrawal fees to a savings account.

'I have real concern over the implications of these charges for the less financially secure or making experienced customers the victims of excessive fees, turning an attempt to create an income from savings into a cash cow for the building society.'

However, savers might be alerted to the quirky account's limitations by the fact that although they can view balances online, it is not possible to open an account on the internet.

Instead, they must either apply in person in branch, contact the building society by phone, or download an application form and post it in.

The withdrawal fees are not clearly listed on the product pages of accounts. For example, on the page of Earl Shilton's instant access cash Isa, paying 1.15 per cent, the charges are not mentioned.

Under a section titled 'can I withdraw money', the building society only says 'yes – instant access'.

The fees are listed under a separate heading on the savings section of the society's website titled 'savings administration fees'.

This then gives you the link to the fees, which shows the withdrawal fees the society has charged for the last two years.

The building society does not reference it withdrawal fees on the pages of its savings products, instead it lists them in a document in a separate section of its website

Given how the cash Isa would pay you £11.50 per year in interest on a balance of £1,000, making a next-day transfer using Faster Payments from the account to your bank account would wipe out all but £1.50 of that interest rate gain.

Its instant access savings account pays even less at 0.25 per cent on balances up to £10,000 and 0.3 per cent on balances between £10,000 and £180,000.

Earl Shilton defended the fees by pointing out that as it has not online withdrawal system for customers to use themselves, each payment out must be processed individually by a member of staff.

A spokesman told This is Money: 'Faster Payments and CHAPS are processed individually and the respective charges reflect the reasonable time and effort of that processing together with the immediacy, or not, of the request, and finally the bank charges incurred by us from our clearing bank.'

The building society's clearing bank is taxpayer-owned high street giant NatWest.

It added: 'Faster payments are only permitted up to £250,000, as advised to us by our clearing bank. This accounts for payments over this sum being required to be sent by CHAPS.'
description: Leicestershire-based Earl Shilton Building Society, which has 'over 10,000 members', does not allow users to transfer money out of its savings accounts online.
